title: Why do Americans think Chinese pinyin 'b' sounds like 'p'? - Quora

response.answer_text: Mandarin “b” and “p” represent different varieties of English “p” Chinese “b” is an unaspirated [p], basically the same sound as English “p” in the word “aPPle” or “sPill” Chinese “p” is an aspirated [p], the same sound as “p” in “Pill” The two English [p] sounds are interchangeable: slightl mispronouncing the words “apple, spill, or pill” will sound odd to English speakers’ ears, but the meaning will remain the same. When English speakers learn Chinese, they may carry over their English habit of not clearly distinguishing between these pairs of Chinese sounds: b~p, d~t, and g~k. This is why they might make mistakes.

It’s something of a leading question. Most native-born Americans have no knowledge of Chinese and thus don’t think much about how b or p are pronounced in Mandarin. When an English-speaking broadcaster says 北京 it will usually be pronounced Bay-jing. 臺北 will be pronounced Tai-pay, or “Type A”. Of course neither is quite correct. The plosive b in 北 is seldom if ever used in standard English, so most native speakers of English don’t get it quite right. Place names get Anglicized by native English speakers. This is not confined to Chinese. The Eiffel Tower is in Paris, not in Pa-ree as our French friends say it. The capital of the EU is Brussels, not Broo-sells. If you want to see Michelangelo's David (and you should!) he lives in Florence, not Firenze. And this goes both ways. I live in Seattle. My home town is not pronounced 西雅圖 or Xi-ya-too, but if you call it that, I’ll know what you mean.
